Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

That's a contrast to how I felt about the character in the early 1990's, when I was in my early 20's. I thought he was hilarious back then. I wasn't mean spirited, I just thought it was all a funny joke. As time went by, I learned that the joke was at the expense of real people. Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I can't stand watching Al Bundy, because some of the things that the character says are deeply offensive, and I can't laugh about that. That's a contrast to how I felt about the character in the early 1990's, when I was in my early 20's. I thought he was hilarious back then. I wasn't mean spirited, I just thought it was all a funny joke. As time went by, I learned that the joke was at the expense of real people. Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? The shows were all taped, and they are identical to what I watched back then, when I watch them today. The only thing that has changed is me. I can't say that society has changed, be

I can't stand watching Al Bundy, because some of the things that the character says are deeply offensive, and I can't laugh about that. That's a contrast to how I felt about the character in the early 1990's, when I was in my early 20's. I thought he was hilarious back then. I wasn't mean spirited, I just thought it was all a funny joke. As time went by, I learned that the joke was at the expense of real people. Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? The shows were all taped, and they are identical to what I watched back then, when I watch them today. The only thing that has changed is me. That's a contrast to how I felt about the character in the early 1990's, when I was in my early 20's. I thought he was hilarious back then. I wasn't mean spirited, I just thought it was all a funny joke. As time went by, I learned that the joke was at the expense of real people. Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? That's a contrast to how I felt about the character in the early 1990's, when I was in my early 20's. I thought he was hilarious back then. I wasn't mean spirited, I just thought it was all a funny joke. As time went by, I learned that the joke was at the expense of real people. Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? The shows were all taped, and they are identical to what I watched back then, when I watch them today. The only thing that has changed is me. I can't say that society has changed, because there isn't a lot of real evidence to suggest that it has. My tipping point seems to be related to my level of expe

I can't stand watching Al Bundy, because some of the things that the character says are deeply offensive, and I can't laugh about that. That's a contrast to how I felt about the character in the early 1990's, when I was in my early 20's. I thought he was hilarious back then. I wasn't mean spirited, I just thought it was all a funny joke. As time went by, I learned that the joke was at the expense of real people. Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? The shows were all taped, and they are identical to what I watched back then, when I watch them today. The only thing that has changed is me. I can't say that society has changed, because there isn't a lot of real evidence to suggest that it has. My tipping point seems to be related to my level of experience, to what I've learned about the world. As I learn more

I wasn't mean spirited, I just thought it was all a funny joke. As time went by, I learned that the joke was at the expense of real people. Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? The shows were all taped, and they are identical to what I watched back then, when I watch them today. The only thing that has changed is me. I can't say that society has changed, because there isn't a lot of real evidence to suggest that it has. My tipping point seems to be related to my level of experience, to what I've learned about the world. As I learn more, some things that I

---

In my opinion, the people who make me cringe on tv change over time. I can't stand watching Al Bundy, because some of the things that the character says are deeply offensive, and I can't laugh about that. That's a contrast to how I felt about the character in the early 1990's, when I was in my early 20's. I thought he was hilarious back then. I wasn't mean spirited, I just thought it was all a funny joke. As time went by, I learned that the joke was at the expense of real people. Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? The shows were all taped, and they are identical to what I watched back then, when I watch them today. The only thing that has changed is me. I can't say that society has changed, because there isn't a lot of real evidence to suggest that it has. My tipping point seems to be related to my level of experience, to what I've learned about the world. As I learn more, some things that I once found funny no longer ha

That's a contrast to how I felt about the character in the early 1990's, when I was in my early 20's. I thought he was hilarious back then. I wasn't mean spirited, I just thought it was all a funny joke. As time went by, I learned that the joke was at the expense of real people. Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? The shows were all taped, and they are identical to what I watched back then, when I watch them today. The only thing that has changed is me. I can't say that society has changed, because there isn't a lot of real evidence to suggest that it has. My tipping point seems to be related to my level of experience, to what I've learned about the world. As I learn more, some things that I once found funny no longer have a balance between funny and wrong, and they tip into o

That's a contrast to how I felt about the character in the early 1990's, when I was in my early 20's. I thought he was hilarious back then. I wasn't mean spirited, I just thought it was all a funny joke. As time went by, I learned that the joke was at the expense of real people. Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? The shows were all taped, and they are identical to what I watched back then, when I watch them today. The only thing that has changed is me. I can't say that society has changed, because there isn't a lot of real evidence to suggest that it has. My tipping point seems to be related to my level of experience, to what I've learned about the world. As I learn more, some things that I once found funny no longer have a balance between funny and wrong, and they tip into offensive territory.
The example that comes to mind is "cracking" on someone's weight.

I can't say that society has changed, because there isn't a lot of real evidence to suggest that it has. My tipping point seems to be related to my level of experience, to what I've learned about the world. As I learn more, some things that I once found funny no longer have a balance between funny and wrong, and they tip into offensive territory.

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the people who make me cringe on tv change over time. I can't stand watching Al Bundy, because some of the things that the character says are deeply offensive, and I can't laugh about that. That's a contrast to how I felt about the character in the early 1990's, when I was in my early 20's. I thought he was hilarious back then. I wasn't mean spirited, I just thought it was all a funny joke. As time went by, I learned that the joke was at the expense of real people. Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? The shows were all taped, and they are identical to what I watched back then, when I watch them today. The only thing that has changed is me. I can't say that society has changed, because there isn't a lot of real evidence to suggest that it has. What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the people who make me cringe on tv change over time. I can't stand watching Al Bundy, because some of the things that the character says are deeply offensive, and I can't laugh about that. That's a contrast to how I felt about the character in the early 1990's, when I was in my early 20's. I thought he was hilarious back then. I wasn't mean spirited, I just thought it was all a funny joke. As time went by, I learned that the joke was at the expense of real people. Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? The shows were all taped, and they are identical to what I watched back then, when I watch them today. The only thing that has changed is me. I can't say that society has changed, because there isn't a lot of real evidence to suggest that it has. My tipping point seems to be related to my level of experience, to what I've learned about the world. As I learn more, some things that I once found funny no longer have a balance between funny and wrong, and they tip into offensive territory.
The example that comes to mind is "cracking" on someone's weight.
 I see people in movies, from time to time, making snide remarks or outright making jokes about another character's weight. Wh

In my opinion, the people who make me cringe on tv change over time. I can't stand watching Al Bundy, because some of the things that the character says are deeply offensive, and I can't laugh about that. That's a contrast to how I felt about the character in the early 1990's, when I was in my early 20's. I thought he was hilarious back then. I wasn't mean spirited, I just thought it was all a funny joke. As time went by, I learned that the joke was at the expense of real people. Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? I wasn't mean spirited, I just thought it was all a funny joke. As time went by, I learned that the joke was at the expense of real people. Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? The shows were all taped, and they are identical to what I watched back then, when I watch them today. The only thing that has changed is me. I can't say that society has changed, because there isn't a lot of real evidence to suggest that it has. My tipping point seems to be related to my level of experience, to what I've learned about the world. As I learn more, some things that I once found funny no longer have a balance between funny and wrong, and they tip into offensive territory.
The example that comes to mind is "cracking" on someone's weight.
 I see people in movies, from time to time, making snide remarks or outright making jokes about another character's weight. When I was young, I thought that was pretty funny.

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

That's a contrast to how I felt about the character in the early 1990's, when I was in my early 20's. I thought he was hilarious back then. I wasn't mean spirited, I just thought it was all a funny joke. As time went by, I learned that the joke was at the expense of real people. Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? The shows were all taped, and they are identical to what I watched back then, when I watch them today. The only thing that has changed is me. I can't say that society has changed, because there isn't a lot of real evidence to suggest that it has. My tipping point seems to be related to my level of experience, to what I've learned about the world. As I learn more, some things that I once found funny no longer have a balance between funny and wrong, and they tip into offensive territory.
The example that comes to mind is "cracking" on someone's weight.
 I see people in movies, from time to time, making snide remarks or outright making jokes about another character's weight. When I was young, I thought that was pretty funny. Now I'm much older and I'm overweight myself. I've talked with man

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the people who make me cringe on tv change over time. I can't stand watching Al Bundy, because some of the things that the character says are deeply offensive, and I can't laugh about that. That's a contrast to how I felt about the character in the early 1990's, when I was in my early 20's. I thought he was hilarious back then. I wasn't mean spirited, I just thought it was all a funny joke. As time went by, I learned that the joke was at the expense of real people. Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? The shows were all taped, and they are identical to what I watched back then, when I watch them today. The only thing that has changed is me. I can't say that society has changed, because there isn't a lot of real evidence to suggest that it has. My tipping point seems to be related to my level of experience, to what I've learned about the world. As I learn more, some things that I once found funny no longer have a balance between funny and wrong, and they tip into offensive territory.
The example that comes to mind is "cracking" on someone's weight.

Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? The shows were all taped, and they are identical to what I watched back then, when I watch them today. The only thing that has changed is me. I can't say that society has changed, because there isn't a lot of real evidence to suggest that it has. My tipping point seems to be related to my level of experience, to what I've learned about the world. As I learn more, some things that I once found funny no longer have a balance between funny and wrong, and they tip into offensive territory.
The example that comes to mind is "cracking" on someone's weight.

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the people who make me cringe on tv change over time. I can't stand watching Al Bundy, because some of the things that the character says are deeply offensive, and I can't laugh about that. That's a contrast to how I felt about the character in the early 1990's, when I was in my early 20's. I thought he was hilarious back then. I wasn't mean spirited, I just thought it was all a funny joke. As time went by, I learned that the joke was at the expense of real people. Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? I can't say that society has changed, because there isn't a lot of real evidence to suggest that it has. My tipping point seems to be related to my level of experience, to what I've learned about the world. As I learn more, some things that I once found funny no longer have a balance between funny and wrong, and they tip into offensive territory.
The example that comes to mind is "cracking" on someone's weight.

I wasn't mean spirited, I just thought it was all a funny joke. As time went by, I learned that the joke was at the expense of real people. Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? The shows were all taped, and they are identical to what I watched back then, when I watch them today. The only thing that has changed is me. I can't say that society has changed, because there isn't a lot of real evidence to suggest that it has. My tipping point seems to be related to my level of experience, to what I've learned about the world. As I learn more, some things that I once found funny no longer have a balance between funny and wrong, and they tip into offensive territory.
The example that comes to mind is "cracking" on someone's weight.
 I see people in movies, from time to time, making snide remarks or outright making jokes about another character's weight. When I was young, I thought that was pretty funny. Now I'm much older and I'm overweight myself. I've talked with many nice people who also struggled with a weight problem. When I see someone making light of that struggle with self image, I c

In my opinion, the people who make me cringe on tv change over time. I can't stand watching Al Bundy, because some of the things that the character says are deeply offensive, and I can't laugh about that. That's a contrast to how I felt about the character in the early 1990's, when I was in my early 20's. I thought he was hilarious back then. I wasn't mean spirited, I just thought it was all a funny joke. As time went by, I learned that the joke was at the expense of real people. Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? The shows were all taped, and they are identical to what I watched back then, when I watch them today. The only thing that has changed is me. I can't say that society has changed, because there isn't a lot of real evidence to suggest that it has. My tipping point seems to be related to my level of experience, to what I've learned about the world. As I learn more, some things that I once found funny no longer have a balance between funny and wrong, and they tip into offensive territory.
The example that comes to mind is "cracking" on someone's weight.

Now I'm much older and I'm overweight myself. I've talked with many nice people who also struggled with a weight problem. When I see someone making light of that struggle with self image, I can't laugh at that anymore. The shows were all taped, and they are identical to what I watched back then, when I watch them today. The only thing that has changed is me. I can't say that society has changed, because there isn't a lot of real evidence to suggest that it has. My tipping point seems to be related to my level of experience, to what I've learned about the world. As I learn more, some things that I once found funny no longer have a balance between funny and wrong, and they tip into offensive territory.
The example that comes to mind is "cracking" on someone's weight.

I can't stand watching Al Bundy, because some of the things that the character says are deeply offensive, and I can't laugh about that. That's a contrast to how I felt about the character in the early 1990's, when I was in my early 20's. I thought he was hilarious back then. I wasn't mean spirited, I just thought it was all a funny joke. As time went by, I learned that the joke was at the expense of real people. Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? The shows were all taped, and they are identical to what I watched back then, when I watch them today. The only thing that has changed is me. I can't say that society has changed, because there isn't a lot of real evidence to suggest that it has. My tipping point seems to be related to my level of experience, to what I've learned about the world. As I learn more, some things that I once found funny no longer have a balance between funny and wrong, and they tip into offensive territory.
The example that comes to mind is "cracking" on someone's weight.
 I see people in movies, from time to time, making snide remarks or outright making jokes about another character's weight. When I was young, I thought that was pretty funny. Now I'm much older and I'm overweight myself. I've talked with many nice people who also struggled with a weight problem. When I see someone making light of that struggle with self image, I can't laugh at that anymore. I now see it as hurtful, and I really don't know how some people continue to laugh at that, because it no longer seems very funny. Yet, not that long ago, in my life, I was laughing

Now I'm much older and I'm overweight myself. I've talked with many nice people who also struggled with a weight problem. When I see someone making light of that struggle with self image, I can't laugh at that anymore. I now see it as hurtful, and I really don't know how some people continue to laugh at that, because it no longer seems very funny. Yet, not that long ago, in my life, I was laughing too.

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the people who make me cringe on tv change over time. I can't stand watching Al Bundy, because some of the things that the character says are deeply offensive, and I can't laugh about that. That's a contrast to how I felt about the character in the early 1990's, when I was in my early 20's. I thought he was hilarious back then. I wasn't mean spirited, I just thought it was all a funny joke. As time went by, I learned that the joke was at the expense of real people. Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? The shows were all taped, and they are identical to what I watched back then, when I watch them today. The only thing that has changed is me. I can't say that society has changed, because there isn't a lot of real evidence to suggest that it has. My tipping point seems to be related to my level of experience, to what I've learned about the world. As I learn more, some things that I once found funny no longer have a balance between funny and wrong, and they tip into offensive territory.

I wasn't mean spirited, I just thought it was all a funny joke. As time went by, I learned that the joke was at the expense of real people. Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? The shows were all taped, and they are identical to what I watched back then, when I watch them today. The only thing that has changed is me. I can't say that society has changed, because there isn't a lot of real evidence to suggest that it has. My tipping point seems to be related to my level of experience, to what I've learned about the world. As I learn more, some things that I once found funny no longer have a balance between funny and wrong, and they tip into offensive territory.
The example that comes to mind is "cracking" on someone's weight.
 I see people in movies, from time to time, making snide remarks or outright making jokes about another character's weight. When I was young, I thought that was pretty funny. Now I'm much older and I'm overweight myself. I've talked with many nice people who also struggled with a weight problem. When I see someone making light of that struggle with self image, I can't laugh at that anymore. I now see it as hurtful, and I really don't know how some people continue to laugh at that, because it no longer seems very funny. Yet, not that long ago, in my life, I was laughing too.

As I learn more, some things that I once found funny no longer have a balance between funny and wrong, and they tip into offensive territory.
The example that comes to mind is "cracking" on someone's weight.
 I see people in movies, from time to time, making snide remarks or outright making jokes about another character's weight. When I was young, I thought that was pretty funny. Now I'm much older and I'm overweight myself. I've talked with many nice people who also struggled with a weight problem. When I see someone making light of that struggle with self image, I can't laugh at that anymore. I now see it as hurtful, and I really don't know how some people continue to laugh at that, because it no longer seems very funny. Yet, not that long ago, in my life, I was laughing too.

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the people who make me cringe on tv change over time. I can't stand watching Al Bundy, because some of the things that the character says are deeply offensive, and I can't laugh about that. That's a contrast to how I felt about the character in the early 1990's, when I was in my early 20's. I thought he was hilarious back then. I wasn't mean spirited, I just thought it was all a funny joke. As time went by, I learned that the joke was at the expense of real people. Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? The shows were all taped, and they are identical to what I watched back then, when I watch them today. The only thing that has changed is me. I can't say that society has changed, because there isn't a lot of real evidence to suggest that it has. My tipping point seems to be related to my level of experience, to what I've learned about the world. As I learn more, some things that I once found funny no longer have a balance between funny and wrong, and they tip into offensive territory.
The example that comes to mind is "cracking" on someone's weight.
 I see people in movies, from time to time, making snide remarks or outright making jokes about another character's weight. When I was young, I thought that was pretty funny. Now I'm much older and I'm overweight myself. I've talked with many nice people who also struggled with a weight problem. When I see someone making light of that struggle with self image, I can't laugh at that anymore. I now see it as hurtful, and I really don't know how some people continue to laugh at that, because it no longer seems very funny. Yet, not that long ago, in my life, I was laughing too.

In my opinion, the people who make me cringe on tv change over time. I can't stand watching Al Bundy, because some of the things that the character says are deeply offensive, and I can't laugh about that. That's a contrast to how I felt about the character in the early 1990's, when I was in my early 20's. I thought he was hilarious back then. I wasn't mean spirited, I just thought it was all a funny joke. As time went by, I learned that the joke was at the expense of real people. Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? The shows were all taped, and they are identical to what I watched back then, when I watch them today. The only thing that has changed is me. I can't say that society has changed, because there isn't a lot of real evidence to suggest that it has. My tipping point seems to be related to my level of experience, to what I've learned about the world. As I learn more, some things that I once found funny no longer have a balance between funny and wrong, and they tip into offensive territory.
The example that comes to mind is "cracking" on someone's weight.
 I see people in movies, from time to time, making snide remarks or outright making jokes about another character's weight. When I was young, I thought that was pretty funny. Now I'm much older and I'm overweight myself. I've talked with many nice people who also struggled with a weight problem. When I see someone making light of that struggle with self image, I can't laugh at that anymore. I now see it as hurtful, and I really don't know how some people continue to laugh at that, because it no longer seems very funny. Yet, not that long ago, in my life, I was laughing too.

As I learn more, some things that I once found funny no longer have a balance between funny and wrong, and they tip into offensive territory.
The example that comes to mind is "cracking" on someone's weight.
 I see people in movies, from time to time, making snide remarks or outright making jokes about another character's weight. When I was young, I thought that was pretty funny. Now I'm much older and I'm overweight myself. I've talked with many nice people who also struggled with a weight problem. When I see someone making light of that struggle with self image, I can't laugh at that anymore. I now see it as hurtful, and I really don't know how some people continue to laugh at that, because it no longer seems very funny. Yet, not that long ago, in my life, I was laughing too.

It's difficult to explain what makes me cringe in a fictional character. It's a combination of the portrayal and the circumstances. The portrayal of Al Bundy wi

Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

That's a contrast to how I felt about the character in the early 1990's, when I was in my early 20's. I thought he was hilarious back then. I wasn't mean spirited, I just thought it was all a funny joke. As time went by, I learned that the joke was at the expense of real people. Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? The shows were all taped, and they are identical to what I watched back then, when I watch them today. The only thing that has changed is me. I can't say that society has changed, because there isn't a lot of real evidence to suggest that it has. My tipping point seems to be related to my level of experience, to what I've learned about the world. As I learn more, some things that I once found funny no longer have a balance between funny and wrong, and they tip into offensive territory.
The example that comes to mind is "cracking" on someone's weight.
 I see people in movies, from time to time, making snide remarks or outright making jokes about another character's weight. When I was young, I thought that was pretty funny. Now I'm much older and I'm overweight myself. I've talked with many nice people who also struggled with a weight problem. When I see someone making light of that struggle with self image, I can't laugh at that anymore. I now see it as hurtful, and I really don't know how some people continue to laugh at that, because it no longer seems very funny. Yet, not that long ago, in my life, I was laughing too.

It's difficult to explain what makes me cringe in a fictional character. It's a combination of the portrayal and the circumstances. The portrayal of Al Bundy will never change, b

 I see people in movies, from time to time, making snide remarks or outright making jokes about another character's weight. When I was young, I thought that was pretty funny. Now I'm much older and I'm overweight myself. I've talked with many nice people who also struggled with a weight problem. When I see someone making light of that struggle with self image, I can't laugh at that anymore. I now see it as hurtful, and I really don't know how some people continue to laugh at that, because it no longer seems very funny. Yet, not that long ago, in my life, I was laughing too.

In my opinion, the people who make me cringe on tv change over time. I can't stand watching Al Bundy, because some of the things that the character says are deeply offensive, and I can't laugh about that. That's a contrast to how I felt about the character in the early 1990's, when I was in my early 20's. I thought he was hilarious back then. I wasn't mean spirited, I just thought it was all a funny joke. As time went by, I learned that the joke was at the expense of real people. Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? The shows were all taped, and they are identical to what I watched back then, when I watch them today. The only thing that has changed is me. I can't say that society has changed, because there isn't a lot of real evidence to suggest that it has. I can't stand watching Al Bundy, because some of the things that the character says are deeply offensive, and I can't laugh about that. That's a contrast to how I felt about the character in the early 1990's, when I was in my early 20's. I thought he was hilarious back then. I wasn't mean spirited, I just thought it was all a funny joke. As time went by, I learned that the joke was at the expense of real people. Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? The shows were all taped, and they are identical to what I watched back then, when I watch them today. The only thing that has changed is me. I can't say that society has changed, because there isn't a lot of real evidence to suggest that it has. My tipping point seems to be related to my level of experience, to what I've learned about the world. As I learn more, some things that I once found funny no longer have a balance between funny and wrong, and they tip into offensive territory.
The example that comes to mind is "cracking" on someone's weight.
 I see people in movies, from time to time, making snide remarks or outright making jokes about another character's weight. When I was young, I thought that was pretty funny. Now I'm much older and I'm overweight myself. I've talked with many nice people who also struggled with a weight problem. When I see someone making light of that struggle with self image, I can't laugh at that anymore. I now see it as hurtful, and I really don't know how some people continue to laugh at that, because it no longer seems very funny. Yet, not that long ago, in my life, I was laughing too.

It's difficult to explain what makes me cringe in a fictional character. It's a combination of the portrayal and the circumstances. The portrayal of Al Bundy will never change, because the show ended a long ti

I can't say that society has changed, because there isn't a lot of real evidence to suggest that it has. My tipping point seems to be related to my level of experience, to what I've learned about the world. As I learn more, some things that I once found funny no longer have a balance between funny and wrong, and they tip into offensive territory.
The example that comes to mind is "cracking" on someone's weight.
 I see people in movies, from time to time, making snide remarks or outright making jokes about another character's weight. When I was young, I thought that was pretty funny. Now I'm much older and I'm overweight myself. I've talked with many nice people who also struggled with a weight problem. When I see someone making light of that struggle with self image, I can't laugh at that anymore. I now see it as hurtful, and I really don't know how some people continue to laugh at that, because it no longer seems very funny. Yet, not that long ago, in my life, I was laughing too.

It's difficult to explain what makes me cringe in a fictional character. It's a combination of the portrayal and the circumstances. The portrayal of Al Bundy will never change, because the show ended a long time ago. The circu

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

I can't stand watching Al Bundy, because some of the things that the character says are deeply offensive, and I can't laugh about that. That's a contrast to how I felt about the character in the early 1990's, when I was in my early 20's. I thought he was hilarious back then. I wasn't mean spirited, I just thought it was all a funny joke. As time went by, I learned that the joke was at the expense of real people. Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

 I see people in movies, from time to time, making snide remarks or outright making jokes about another character's weight. When I was young, I thought that was pretty funny. Now I'm much older and I'm overweight myself. I've talked with many nice people who also struggled with a weight problem. When I see someone making light of that struggle with self image, I can't laugh at that anymore. I now see it as hurtful, and I really don't know how some people continue to laugh at that, because it no longer seems very funny. Yet, not that long ago, in my life, I was laughing too.

It's difficult to explain what makes me cringe in a fictional character. It's a combination of the portrayal and the circumstances. The portrayal of Al Bundy will never change, because the show ended a long time ago. The circumstances have ch

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the people who make me cringe on tv change over time. I can't stand watching Al Bundy, because some of the things that the character says are deeply offensive, and I can't laugh about that. That's a contrast to how I felt about the character in the early 1990's, when I was in my early 20's. I thought he was hilarious back then. I wasn't mean spirited, I just thought it was all a funny joke. As time went by, I learned that the joke was at the expense of real people. Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? The shows were all taped, and they are identical to what I watched back then, when I watch them today. The only thing that has changed is me. I can't say that society has changed, because there isn't a lot of real evidence to suggest that it has. My tipping point seems to be related to my level of experience, to what I've learned about the world. I now see it as hurtful, and I really don't know how some people continue to laugh at that, because it no longer seems very funny. Yet, not that long ago, in my life, I was laughing too.

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the people who make me cringe on tv change over time. I can't stand watching Al Bundy, because some of the things that the character says are deeply offensive, and I can't laugh about that. That's a contrast to how I felt about the character in the early 1990's, when I was in my early 20's. I thought he was hilarious back then. I wasn't mean spirited, I just thought it was all a funny joke. As time went by, I learned that the joke was at the expense of real people. Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? The shows were all taped, and they are identical to what I watched back then, when I watch them today. The only thing that has changed is me. I can't say that society has changed, because there isn't a lot of real evidence to suggest that it has. My tipping point seems to be related to my level of experience, to what I've learned about the world. As I learn more, some things that I once found funny no longer have a balance between funny and wrong, and they tip into offensive territory.
The example that comes to mind is "cracking" on someone's weight.
 I see people in movies, from time to time, making snide remarks or outright making jokes about another character's weight. When I was young, I thought that was pretty funny. Now I'm much older and I'm overweight myself. I've talked with many nice people who also struggled with a weight problem. When I see someone making light of that struggle with self image, I can't laugh at that anymore. I now see it as hurtful, and I really don't know how some people continue to laugh at that, because it no longer seems very funny. Yet, not that long ago, in my life, I was laughing too.

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the people who make me cringe on tv change over time. I can't stand watching Al Bundy, because some of the things that the character says are deeply offensive, and I can't laugh about that. That's a contrast to how I felt about the character in the early 1990's, when I was in my early 20's. I thought he was hilarious back then. I wasn't mean spirited, I just thought it was all a funny joke. As time went by, I learned that the joke was at the expense of real people. Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? The shows were all taped, and they are identical to what I watched back then, when I watch them today. The only thing that has changed is me. I can't say that society has changed, because there isn't a lot of real evidence to suggest that it has. My tipping point seems to be related to my level of experience, to what I've learned about the world. As I learn more, some things that I once found funny no longer have a balance between funny and wrong, and they tip into offensive territory.
The example that comes to mind is "cracking" on someone's weight.
 I see people in movies, from time to time, making snide remarks or outright making jokes about another character's weight. When I was young, I thought that was pretty funny. Now I'm much older and I'm overweight myself. I've talked with many nice people who also struggled with a weight problem. When I see someone making light of that struggle with self image, I can't laugh at that anymore. I now see it as hurtful, and I really don't know how some people continue to laugh at that, because it no longer seems very funny. Yet, not that long ago, in my life, I was laughing too.

It's difficult to explain what makes me cringe in a fictional character. It's a combination of the portrayal and the circumstances. The portrayal of Al Bundy will never change, because the show ended a long time ago. The circumstances have changed because, with age and experi

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the people who make me cringe on tv change over time. I can't stand watching Al Bundy, because some of the things that the character says are deeply offensive, and I can't laugh about that. That's a contrast to how I felt about the character in the early 1990's, when I was in my early 20's. I thought he was hilarious back then. I wasn't mean spirited, I just thought it was all a funny joke. As time went by, I learned that the joke was at the expense of real people. Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? The shows were all taped, and they are identical to what I watched back then, when I watch them today. The only thing that has changed is me. I can't say that society has changed, because there isn't a lot of real evidence to suggest that it has. My tipping point seems to be related to my level of experience, to what I've learned about the world. As I learn more, some things that I once found funny no longer have a balance between funny and wrong, and they tip into offensive territory.
The example that comes to mind is "cracking" on someone's weight.
 I see people in movies, from time to time, making snide remarks or outright making jokes about another character's weight. When I was young, I thought that was pretty funny. Now I'm much older and I'm overweight myself. I've talked with many nice people who also struggled with a weight problem. When I see someone making light of that struggle with self image, I can't laugh at that anymore. I now see it as hurtful, and I really don't know how some people continue to laugh at that, because it no longer seems very funny. Yet, not that long ago, in my life, I was laughing too.

It's difficult to explain what makes me cringe in a fictional character. It's a combination of the portrayal and the circumstances. The portrayal of Al Bundy will never change, because the show ended a long time ago. The circumstances have changed because, with age and experience, I've learn

When I see someone making light of that struggle with self image, I can't laugh at that anymore. I now see it as hurtful, and I really don't know how some people continue to laugh at that, because it no longer seems very funny. Yet, not that long ago, in my life, I was laughing too.

It's difficult to explain what makes me cringe in a fictional character. It's a combination of the portrayal and the circumstances. The portrayal of Al Bundy will never change, because the show ended a long time ago. The circumstances have changed because, with age and experience, I've learned to approach l

What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the people who make me cringe on tv change over time. I can't stand watching Al Bundy, because some of the things that the character says are deeply offensive, and I can't laugh about that. That's a contrast to how I felt about the character in the early 1990's, when I was in my early 20's. I thought he was hilarious back then. I wasn't mean spirited, I just thought it was all a funny joke. As time went by, I learned that the joke was at the expense of real people. Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? The shows were all taped, and they are identical to what I watched back then, when I watch them today. The only thing that has changed is me. I can't say that society has changed, because there isn't a lot of real evidence to suggest that it has. My tipping point seems to be related to my level of experience, to what I've learned about the world. As I learn more, some things that I once found funny no longer have a balance between funny and wrong, and they tip into offensive territory.
The example that comes to mind is "cracking" on someone's weight.

As I learn more, some things that I once found funny no longer have a balance between funny and wrong, and they tip into offensive territory.
The example that comes to mind is "cracking" on someone's weight.
 I see people in movies, from time to time, making snide remarks or outright making jokes about another character's weight. When I was young, I thought that was pretty funny. Now I'm much older and I'm overweight myself. I've talked with many nice people who also struggled with a weight problem. When I see someone making light of that struggle with self image, I can't laugh at that anymore. I now see it as hurtful, and I really don't know how some people continue to laugh at that, because it no longer seems very funny. Yet, not that long ago, in my life, I was laughing too.

It's difficult to explain what makes me cringe in a fictional character. It's a combination of the portrayal and the circumstances. The portrayal of Al Bundy will never change, because the show ended a long time ago. The circumstances have changed because, with age and experience, I've learned to approach life with more emp

I wasn't mean spirited, I just thought it was all a funny joke. As time went by, I learned that the joke was at the expense of real people. Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? The shows were all taped, and they are identical to what I watched back then, when I watch them today. The only thing that has changed is me. I can't say that society has changed, because there isn't a lot of real evidence to suggest that it has. My tipping point seems to be related to my level of experience, to what I've learned about the world. As I learn more, some things that I once found funny no longer have a balance between funny and wrong, and they tip into offensive territory.
The example that comes to mind is "cracking" on someone's weight.
 I see people in movies, from time to time, making snide remarks or outright making jokes about another character's weight. When I was young, I thought that was pretty funny. Now I'm much older and I'm overweight myself. I've talked with many nice people who also struggled with a weight problem. When I see someone making light of that struggle with self image, I can't laugh at that anymore. I now see it as hurtful, and I really don't know how some people continue to laugh at that, because it no longer seems very funny. Yet, not that long ago, in my life, I was laughing too.

It's difficult to explain what makes me cringe in a fictional character. It's a combination of the portrayal and the circumstances. The portrayal of Al Bundy will never change, because the show ended a long time ago. The circumstances have changed because, with age and experience, I've learned to approach life with more empathy. What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the people who make me cringe on tv change over time. I can't stand watching Al Bundy, because some of the things that the character says are deeply offensive, and I can't laugh about that. That's a contrast to how I felt about the character in the early 1990's, when I was in my early 20's. I thought he was hilarious back then. I wasn't mean spirited, I just thought it was all a funny joke. As time went by, I learned that the joke was at the expense of real people. Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? The shows were all taped, and they are identical to what I watched back then, when I watch them today. The only thing that has changed is me. I can't say that society has changed, because there isn't a lot of real evidence to suggest that it has. My tipping point seems to be related to my level of experience, to what I've learned about the world. As I learn more, some things that I once found funny no longer have a balance between funny and wrong, and they tip into offensive territory.
The example that comes to mind is "cracking" on someone's weight.
 I see people in movies, from time to time, making snide remarks or outright making jokes about another character's weight. When I was young, I thought that was pretty funny. Now I'm much older and I'm overweight myself. I've talked with many nice people who also struggled with a weight problem. When I see someone making light of that struggle with self image, I can't laugh at that anymore. I now see it as hurtful, and I really don't know how some people continue to laugh at that, because it no longer seems very funny. Yet, not that long ago, in my life, I was laughing too.

It's difficult to explain what makes me cringe in a fictional character. It's a combination of the portrayal and the circumstances. The portrayal of Al Bundy will never change, because the show ended a long time ago. The circumstances have changed because, with age and experience, I've learned to approach life with more empathy. I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? The shows were all taped, and they are identical to what I watched back then, when I watch them today. The only thing that has changed is me. I can't say that society has changed, because there isn't a lot of real evidence to suggest that it has. My tipping point seems to be related to my level of experience, to what I've learned about the world. As I learn more, some things that I once found funny no longer have a balance between funny and wrong, and they tip into offensive territory.
The example that comes to mind is "cracking" on someone's weight.
 I see people in movies, from time to time, making snide remarks or outright making jokes about another character's weight. When I was young, I thought that was pretty funny. Now I'm much older and I'm overweight myself. I've talked with many nice people who also struggled with a weight problem. When I see someone making light of that struggle with self image, I can't laugh at that anymore. I now see it as hurtful, and I really don't know how some people continue to laugh at that, because it no longer seems very funny. Yet, not that long ago, in my life, I was laughing too.

It's difficult to explain what makes me cringe in a fictional character. It's a combination of the portrayal and the circumstances. The portrayal of Al Bundy will never change, because the show ended a long time ago. The circumstances have changed because, with age and experience, I've learned to approach life with more empathy. It's difficult to explain what makes me cringe in a fictional character. It's a combination of the portrayal and the circumstances. What Stereotypical Characters Make You Cringe?

What stereotypical characters in books, movies or television shows make you cringe and why? Would you ever not watch or read something because of its offensive portrayal of someone?

---

In my opinion, the people who make me cringe on tv change over time. I can't stand watching Al Bundy, because some of the things that the character says are deeply offensive, and I can't laugh about that. That's a contrast to how I felt about the character in the early 1990's, when I was in my early 20's. I thought he was hilarious back then. I wasn't mean spirited, I just thought it was all a funny joke. As time went by, I learned that the joke was at the expense of real people. Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? The shows were all taped, and they are identical to what I watched back then, when I watch them today. The only thing that has changed is me. I can't say that society has changed, because there isn't a lot of real evidence to suggest that it has. My tipping point seems to be related to my level of experience, to what I've learned about the world. As I learn more, some things that I once found funny no longer have a balance between funny and wrong, and they tip into offensive territory.
The example that comes to mind is "cracking" on someone's weight.
 I see people in movies, from time to time, making snide remarks or outright making jokes about another character's weight. When I was young, I thought that was pretty funny. Now I'm much older and I'm overweight myself. I've talked with many nice people who also struggled with a weight problem. When I see someone making light of that struggle with self image, I can't laugh at that anymore. I now see it as hurtful, and I really don't know how some people continue to laugh at that, because it no longer seems very funny. Yet, not that long ago, in my life, I was laughing too.

It's difficult to explain what makes me cringe in a fictional character. It's a combination of the portrayal and the circumstances. The portrayal of Al Bundy will never change, because the show ended a long time ago. The circumstances have changed because, with age and experience, I've learned to approach life with more empathy. I can't stand watching Al Bundy, because some of the things that the character says are deeply offensive, and I can't laugh about that. That's a contrast to how I felt about the character in the early 1990's, when I was in my early 20's. I thought he was hilarious back then. I wasn't mean spirited, I just thought it was all a funny joke. As time went by, I learned that the joke was at the expense of real people. Instead of laughing, I began feeling uncomfortable and uncertain that I wanted to watch that program anymore.

I wonder sometimes if the things I'm laughing at today, that comedians say or do, will some day be as offensive to me as Al Bundy has become. What will be my tipping point for comedy? The shows were all taped, and they are identical to what I watched back then, when I watch them today. The only thing that has changed is me. I can't say that society has changed, because there isn't a lot of real evidence to suggest that it has. My tipping point seems to be related to my level of experience, to what I've learned about the world. As I learn more, some things that I once found funny no longer have a balance between funny and wrong, and they tip into offensive territory.
The example that comes to mind is "cracking" on someone's weight.
 I see people in movies, from time to time, making snide remarks or outright making jokes about another character's weight. When I was young, I thought that was pretty funny. Now I'm much older and I'm overweight myself. I've talked with many nice people who also struggled with a weight problem. When I see someone making light of that struggle with self image, I can't laugh at that anymore. I now see it as hurtful, and I really don't know how some people continue to laugh at that, because it no longer seems very funny. Yet, not that long ago, in my life, I was laughing too.

It's difficult to explain what makes me cringe in a fictional character. It's a combination of the portrayal and the circumstances. The portrayal of Al Bundy will never change, because the show ended a long time ago. The circumstances have changed because, with age and experience, I've learned to approach life with more empathy. I think that, in the end, cringeworthy material is a matter that is too p

I can't say that society has changed, because there isn't a lot of real evidence to suggest that it has. My tipping point seems to be related to my level of experience, to what I've learned about the world. As I learn more, some things that I once found funny no longer have a balance between funny and wrong, and they tip into offensive territory.
The example that comes to mind is "cracking" on someone's weight.
 I see people in movies, from time to time, making snide remarks or outright making jokes about another character's weight. When I was young, I thought that was pretty funny. Now I'm much older and I'm overweight myself. I've talked with many nice people who also struggled with a weight problem. When I see someone making light of that struggle with self image, I can't laugh at that anymore. I now see it as hurtful, and I really don't know how some people continue to laugh at that, because it no longer seems very funny. Yet, not that long ago, in my life, I was laughing too.

It's difficult to explain what makes me cringe in a fictional character. It's a combination of the portrayal and the circumstances. The portrayal of Al Bundy will never change, because the show ended a long time ago. The circumstances have changed because, with age and experience, I've learned to approach life with more empathy. I think that, in the end, cringeworthy material is a matter that is too personal to lebe
